quotes.topic_title: Cold open: why strategy is hard
quotes.text: You have to have answers to five questions. What's your winning aspiration? Where to play? How can you win? What capabilities do you have to have that your competitors don't? And then, what enabling management systems do you have to put in place?
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical, repeatable framework (the strategy choice cascade) for turning strategy into a set of explicit choices and requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: why strategy is hard
quotes.text: You have to be either differentiated or low cost, there's no way to protect yourself if you're not one of those two.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A sharp strategic constraint that forces practitioners to pick a defensible basis for advantage rather than trying to be “good at everything.”

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: why strategy is hard
quotes.text: I have never met this mythical beast called a great natural strategist. Great strategists have all one thing in common, they just practice.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Reframes strategy as a learnable skill built through deliberate practice, not innate talent—implying teams can improve systematically.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: why strategy is hard
quotes.text: What's taught now in business schools generally sucks. People aren't prepared educationally, and they sure don't get prepared for it in companies. It's intellectually challenging and it's emotionally intimidating.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Explains why strategy is hard in practice: it’s under-taught and demands both integrative thinking and emotional resilience.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We delve into the five questions that you need to answer to help you craft your strategy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a concrete, question-driven framework practitioners can use to build a strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode is for anyone who is trying to build their strategic thinking muscle.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames strategy as a learnable skill that can be developed through practice, not just intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This is the most tactical and fascinating conversation I've had on this podcast about developing a strategy, and that is a really high bar.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Signals the discussion will emphasize practical, step-by-step strategy development rather than abstract theory.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy isn’t just for executives
quotes.text: So, recently there was a newspaper article saying that, pointing out that 10% of the S&P 500 CEOs, 10% are ex Proctor and Gamble people.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A striking data point used to motivate why P&G’s approach to developing strategic talent deep in the org may produce disproportionate leadership outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy isn’t just for executives
quotes.text: Proctor understands that that individual, not the CEO, not the global president of beauty care, not the head of haircare, not the head of shampoos and conditioners, the brand manager makes super important strategic choices, and if they don't make them well, the brand does terribly.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive model of where strategy actually happens: consequential strategic decisions are made several levels down, not just at the top.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy isn’t just for executives
quotes.text: So, I'm a big believer that people down organization have to make really important strategic choices or bad things are going to happen, if they make really great ones, good things are going to happen, and they get trained to be a CEO someday.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that organizations should deliberately empower and train frontline leaders to make strategic choices as a leadership pipeline.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy isn’t just for executives
quotes.text: What is most normal is people at the top do strategy, and people down below do something, and it's usually called execution, and I hate that, I hate that term of art, for what it's worth.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional strategy-vs-execution split and argues it undermines strategic thinking throughout the organization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We all know that your website shouldn't be a static asset, it should be a dynamic part of your strategy that drives conversions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Reframes a website as an active strategic lever tied to conversion outcomes, not just a marketing artifact.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But here's a number for you, 54% of leaders say web updates take too long.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point highlighting how speed of iteration is a widespread bottleneck for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their visual first platform allows you to build, launch, and optimize webpages fast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable emphasis on shortening the build-launch-optimize loop to support faster experimentation and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features, like SAML authentication, and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical heads-up for SaaS builders on predictable enterprise requirements that can shape roadmap planning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale, while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable description of the scalability/flexibility tradeoff solved by a Zanzibar-based authorization approach.

quotes.topic_title: Why people are bad at strategy
quotes.text: Perhaps the thing that makes it intellectually hardest is that it is an integrative activity. It answers to a bunch of questions that have to fit together and reinforce one another.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Frames strategy as a system of mutually reinforcing choices, not a set of independent decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Why people are bad at strategy
quotes.text: Strategy involves making choices to do some things and not other things, and it is often intimidating to say, oh dear, I have to cut these things off, and not do them, and actually make a decision that I'll be held accountable for potentially, or I'll even hold myself accountable for.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Highlights that the hardest part of strategy is often emotional—committing to tradeoffs and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Why people are bad at strategy
quotes.text: It's intellectually challenging and it's emotionally intimidating.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A memorable diagnostic that separates strategy difficulty into two distinct failure modes: thinking and courage.

quotes.topic_title: Why people are bad at strategy
quotes.text: So, people aren't prepared educationally for it, and if they're not prepared educationally for it, then they sure don't get prepared for it in companies.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim that most organizations can’t rely on schools or employers to teach strategy, so practitioners must self-train.

quotes.topic_title: Business school strategy and the RBV critique
quotes.text: Now, the problem is, any resource that may be useful somewhere is not necessarily useful elsewhere. So, it begs the question, how would you think through what resources to invest in building? What would be a way of doing that, investing here, versus here, versus here?
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical critique practitioners can use to pressure-test capability-building plans: resources only matter relative to where you’ll compete, so investment choices need a selection logic.

quotes.topic_title: Business school strategy and the RBV critique
quotes.text: And so, when the students go out and say to their company, I'm going to do a VRIO analysis, or a VRIN, some people just roll their eyes at them, and so it doesn't get used. I've only seen it used, I've been in consulting companies for 42 years, and I've seen it used once.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A specific real-world adoption data point warning that popular academic tools may have low credibility and usage in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Business school strategy and the RBV critique
quotes.text: And that's why the model I use for strategies says a lot about where you play is important, that's one of the key questions, and your capabilities are important, and you've got to link those things together.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concise strategy framework: explicitly connect “where to play” choices with the capabilities required to win there.

quotes.topic_title: Business school strategy and the RBV critique
quotes.text: But if you took the 49 other top business schools in America, and if asked the question, do you swear allegiance to the resource-based view of the firm? If you don't answer an enthusiastic yes, you have no chance of being hired, zero.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about academic incentives shaping what gets taught and hired, which can explain the gap between strategy theory and practitioner needs.

quotes.topic_title: Where Helmer and Rumelt fit in
quotes.text: he's written a very, I think, useful book that would in some sense fit into my how to win box, right? I say strategies about how to win, and he has a, what I call, a categorical model. Here are categories of things that you should think about. If you're trying to win, here are seven ways of winning, and I categorize him as a non-academic practical strategy guy.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Positions Helmer’s “7 ways of winning” as a practical, category-based tool for designing a strategy focused on how to win.

quotes.topic_title: Where Helmer and Rumelt fit in
quotes.text: Mike Porter never in his entire life has said competition is stable, he's repeatedly said the opposite.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Challenges a common caricature of Porter and warns practitioners to verify what influential thinkers actually claim before building strategy on secondhand interpretations.

quotes.topic_title: Where Helmer and Rumelt fit in
quotes.text: I don't think that he, like most business academics, he doesn't know much about business. He hasn't gone out and practiced a lot.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A cautionary heuristic for practitioners: weigh strategy ideas by the author’s real-world operating/consulting exposure, not just academic status.

quotes.topic_title: Where Helmer and Rumelt fit in
quotes.text: And what he said about Proctor and Gamble had zero to do with reality, like zero. It was just completely, utterly, absolutely wrong. And I asked him afterwards, just sort of like, "Why do you say that?" And he said, "Well, I think that's the way it worked."
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Concrete example underscoring the risk of strategy narratives untethered from facts—encouraging leaders to pressure-test claims against operational reality.

quotes.topic_title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
quotes.text: Strategy is an integrated set of choices that compels desired customer action.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A crisp definition that frames strategy as a coherent set of decisions aimed at driving customer behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
quotes.text: So, the way I think about it is, there's a whole bunch of things a company controls, how many factories to build, how much R&D to do, in what areas, and how much advertising to do, how many people to hire, what to pay them, blah, blah, blah... Those are all the things under our control.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Clarifies the controllable “choice set” leaders should focus on when crafting strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
quotes.text: Yeah. We would like them to take some of these out of their pocket and give them to us, can we make them? No, we can't.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that companies can’t force customer behavior—only influence it through choices.

quotes.topic_title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
quotes.text: So, essentially, the job of strategy is to make decisions on the things we do control that will compel, we can't force, but it'll compel them.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: strategy is about selecting controllable decisions that increase the odds customers choose you.

quotes.topic_title: Defining strategy: choices that compel customers
quotes.text: So, the important pieces of it is integrated, it's the whole set of choices that has that one outcome, that it compels desired customer action.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Emphasizes that strategy isn’t a single decision but an integrated system of choices aligned to one outcome.

quotes.topic_title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
quotes.text: I came to the view that you have to have answers to five questions.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Introduces the core methodology (the five-question cascade) as a practical way to build a real strategy.

quotes.topic_title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
quotes.text: You have to have an answer to the question of, what's your winning aspiration? What are you trying to accomplish? Because it'll help contextualize the kinds of choices you could make.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Emphasizes starting strategy with a clear definition of what “winning” means to guide all downstream choices.

quotes.topic_title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
quotes.text: Then there's a where to play, on what playing field, or if you're like military stuff, battlefield, are you going to plop yourself down on? You're not going to play everywhere, in every product, at every vertical stage around the world, you're going to pick someplace, and in that place, how can you be either better than competitors, in terms of creating customer value, or lower cost than those competitors?
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Defines the critical scoping choice (where to play) and ties it directly to a concrete win condition (differentiation or cost).

quotes.topic_title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
quotes.text: To win there, where you've chosen to play to meet your winning aspirations, what capabilities do you have to have that your competitors don't, that would enable you to win that way? And then, what management systems, enabling management systems, do you have to put in place to make sure you build and maintain those must have capabilities to win, where you've chosen to play, to meet your winning aspiration?
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Connects strategy to execution by specifying the unique capabilities required and the systems needed to sustain them.

quotes.topic_title: The strategy choice cascade: five questions
quotes.text: And I came to the conclusion, actually it was in 1995, the end of an eight-year journey, I came to the conclusion those were the five, and you had to do them together, and that is the essence of producing a strategy that compels desired customer action.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Highlights that the cascade works as an integrated set—answering all five together is what makes strategy effective in the market.

quotes.topic_title: Playing to win vs playing to play
quotes.text: It would be mainly signs given to you by customers.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic: whether you’re winning is revealed by customer behavior, not internal narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Playing to win vs playing to play
quotes.text: So, you'll know you're playing to play if you're not aiming to, and accomplishing, having either an offer where Lenny walks into the store, whatever kind of store it is, and says to the person in the store, I want that brand.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concrete “playing to win” test: customers should explicitly prefer you (not treat it like a coin flip).

quotes.topic_title: Playing to win vs playing to play
quotes.text: It turns out that if you do market research on kids, a store that purports to be a toy store but that doesn't have Lego is not a toy store.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Memorable example of extreme differentiation—your category can be defined by your presence.

quotes.topic_title: Playing to win vs playing to play
quotes.text: Well, or get out of business, whatever... It's only a matter of time until you're dead, is the sad truth of the matter, which is the competitors in your industry, who are either low cost or differentiated, can essentially jerk you around as much as they want.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Contrarian warning: without low-cost or differentiation, you’re structurally vulnerable and strategy should change fields—or exit.

quotes.topic_title: Playing to win vs playing to play
quotes.text: It's literally like having a bully who can just shove you, and you take one step back, then they shove you, and you take another step back, and they shove you, and you take another step back.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A vivid mental model for what happens competitively when you lack defensible advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
quotes.text: You've got to ask yourself the question, can I serve a particular customer need with a set of capabilities that are going to be hard to replicate by my competitors? They either can't do it, or they won't do it.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical differentiation test: advantage comes from capabilities competitors can’t or won’t copy, not just a better offering.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
quotes.text: Did they? They didn't. They said, I hope this online thing doesn't really take off because that would be a pisser because we've got 5,000 stores across America, and we've got all that, and that would be a bummer.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A contrarian explanation of competitive advantage: incumbents may choose inaction due to fear of cannibalization, creating openings for challengers.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
quotes.text: Same with Tesla, Tesla got a 10 year headstart, not because the OEMs couldn't, they could have, and of course GM did many, many years ago, create a fully functioning electric vehicle. But they couldn't figure out how the hell you make a buck on it, and so they didn't do it, giving Tesla the ability to establish a brand that people associate with that, electric vehicle equals Tesla, and allow them to jump way ahead, and then have the scale that is hard to hard for others to match.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how incumbent incentives and uncertainty about profitability can grant entrants a long head start and durable scale/brand advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
quotes.text: You have to answer a second question I guess, which is, here's the way I'm going to be better, and here's the way somebody else isn't going to be able to simply replicate that quickly.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A memorable methodology: “better” only matters if you can explain why it won’t be quickly copied.

quotes.topic_title: Differentiation needs defensible capabilities
quotes.text: How does Westlaw do that? Well, for now over 100 years, they've taken every case that's come out of the US legal system, had a lawyer, a Westlaw lawyer, write a head note that summarizes what's in the case, using these keywords so that they were searchable, and today, to do 2024, takes 1500 full-time lawyers.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A specific, defensible-capabilities example (time, process, and scale) illustrating why some advantages are prohibitively hard to replicate.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Cycle unifies all of your customer interactions, from support chats, to user research, gong calls, and app store reviews into one neat collaborative space.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology for consolidating fragmented feedback sources into a single system of record.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Cycle's AI then extracts actionable insights on autopilot.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear automation promise: turning raw feedback into usable insights without manual analysis overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That means you'll get a full voice of customer report without manually triaging feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete operational outcome practitioners can aim for: VOC reporting with minimal manual triage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What makes Cycle different is the way that it lets you close feedback loops in each release.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A release-by-release feedback-loop closure model that can be adopted as a product operating cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Feedback is not used just as a way to prioritize what to build, but also as a tool that creates trust with all stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing of feedback as a trust-building mechanism, not only a prioritization input.

quotes.topic_title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
quotes.text: Yeah. That's why I like Helmer, because he categorizes them.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Points practitioners to using Helmer’s categorized “powers” as a practical way to think about different kinds of moats/barriers.

quotes.topic_title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
quotes.text: But I don't, myself, have a categorization scheme that says, here's how you search for the moat.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A candid reminder that even experts may not have a universal method—useful for avoiding false certainty when assessing defensibility.

quotes.topic_title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
quotes.text: "I look for economic castles protected by unbreachable moats."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for strategy: focus on durable competitive protection, not just building a “castle.”

quotes.topic_title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
quotes.text: Anybody who thinks they can be perfect on strategy is delusional.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Actionable expectation-setting: plan for mistakes and uncertainty rather than assuming flawless strategic calls.

quotes.topic_title: Moats, replication barriers, and Westlaw example
quotes.text: We talked about that with Hamilton Helmer, that every startup deck has, here's our moats, here's how we're going to have barriers to entry, and they're all delusional, rarely is there ever an actual moat, especially in the early stages.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical warning for founders/operators to be skeptical of “moat” claims early on and validate defensibility over time.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
quotes.text: So, there's a big market over there, we'd like to get some, is a terrible reason in my view.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A sharp warning against using market size as the primary rationale for entering a space, pushing teams to ground strategy in customer need.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
quotes.text: The reason should be, customers are bereft, customers are lacking something that we can provide.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for whether an investment/strategy is justified: it should solve a real, felt customer deficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
quotes.text: And most entries by foreign companies into China, they get their faces shot off. And the reason is the rationale is, it's big, we could get some of that.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A memorable example illustrating how “big market” thinking leads to predictable failure when not anchored in a differentiated customer value proposition.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
quotes.text: Because remember, what is strategy about? Compelling desired customer action.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concise definition of strategy that can guide decisions: every choice should connect to driving specific customer behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the cascade to FigJam
quotes.text: To what extent is it a finished product or a component? Because sometimes it could be, we'd like to supply this component that could be integrated into other people's products.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concrete “where-to-play” dimension teams often miss: deciding whether you’re building a standalone product or a component changes the whole strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
quotes.text: At what vertical stage? Is it an integrated product, where it's the whole thing from soup to nuts? Is it some upstream pieces that some people downstream? Do we take pieces from other people and assemble them? So, we're the integrator? Those are all important where to play choices, from my view, because those make a big difference.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Expands “where-to-play” into a concrete value-chain/vertical-integration checklist practitioners can use to clarify strategic positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
quotes.text: Like Four Seasons chose... Four Seasons the hotel company, luxury hotel, chose a completely different choice on the vertical stage where to play, back in the 80s, they said we're going to get out of real estate development... So buying land and getting it zoned for hotels. We're going to get out of construction, building hotels. We're even going to get out of the business of owning the land or the hotel, so that we can be awesome at hotel management.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A vivid example of an asset-light value-chain choice that reallocates focus to the capability that differentiates (management/brand).

quotes.topic_title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
quotes.text: That is a where to play choice. Even though somebody could say, well, you're a luxury hotel, you're like the other luxury hotels who serve luxury customers at a high price. Oh no, no, no, no, no, they do it with a stack this thick, we do it with a stack this thin.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Highlights how two companies can target the same customer segment but win via radically different value-chain structures.

quotes.topic_title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
quotes.text: And everybody has value chain questions. They often complain, after the fact, like all the apps complain about what cut Apple is taking, but they made a choice, a value chain choice.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Reframes platform dependence as a strategic choice (not an inevitability), pushing teams to own the consequences of distribution decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Where-to-play includes value chain choices
quotes.text: No, but would I say, oh, those poor apps, right? Yeah, no, get your own distribution channel, buddy.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable takeaway: if you don’t control distribution, you’re choosing to accept platform power—and should plan accordingly.

quotes.topic_title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
quotes.text: Essentially, you've got to have a theory there, of how are you going to be better or lower cost.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A crisp strategy test: articulate an explicit how-to-win hypothesis (differentiation or cost advantage) rather than a vague plan.

quotes.topic_title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
quotes.text: That's not advice I give. I think they're both completely legitimate strategies. They have implications.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Contradicts the common “never compete on price” trope and reframes cost leadership vs differentiation as valid choices with tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
quotes.text: So, if you want to be the cost leader, it is rare that you can be the cost leader without having dominant scale in the territory in which you're operating.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Actionable constraint: cost leadership usually requires a scale plan, not just operational efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
quotes.text: So, Vanguard had to make a race to, we're going to do index mutual funds, and it doesn't exist now, we're going to do it and we're going to get gigantic, and we can't let anybody get close to us in size because we want to have the lowest cost position.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Concrete example of committing to scale as the mechanism that makes a low-cost strategy defensible.

quotes.topic_title: How to win: low cost vs differentiation tradeoffs
quotes.text: When you think about the costs of differentiation, it's often spending on branding, spending on R&D, R&D innovation. Those two are of the most scale sensitive elements of anybody's cost structure. And so, being a niche-y differentiator is getting harder and harder in my view.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point: differentiation can be highly scale-dependent too, making “small niche differentiator” strategies increasingly difficult.

quotes.topic_title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
quotes.text: Well, I guess I'd ask myself questions, like, is there a learning curve to this, where we could have better capabilities because we started earlier than anybody else, and have more essentially cumulative experience?
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question for identifying capability advantages rooted in experience and compounding learning curves.

quotes.topic_title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
quotes.text: How to win is a theory of how customers are going to perceive us better, if we're differentiated. And then, it's what capabilities would we have to have to make that theory come true, rather than just be a wish.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A crisp mental model: treat strategy as a testable theory that must be operationalized via concrete capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
quotes.text: So, if we want them to feel like we're the easiest to deal with, we have to have capabilities to do that.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: Actionable reminder that customer-facing positioning only works if supported by real operational capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
quotes.text: It's just like again, Four Seasons said the reason they're by far and away the most successful, profitable, best in all fronts, luxury hotel chain in the world... Biggest, best, most profitable, best employee rankings, best guest rankings, all of those.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how a clear how-to-win choice can correlate with broad performance outcomes across stakeholders.

quotes.topic_title: Capabilities: making the how-to-win real
quotes.text: Well, their how to win was they said, people, if you talk to people who are in luxury hotels, they'd rather not be there.
quotes.speaker: Roger Martin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive customer insight that can unlock differentiated strategy by reframing what “luxury” guests actually want.
